I have a strong experience in proteomics-based mass spectrometry, working with large data sets, usually the whole proteome of yeast, yeast mitochondria, human cancer cell lines and other cell types. Most of my work was quantifying large-scale (phospho)proteomes and (phospho)peptides using labelling techniques such as TMT, iTRAQ or label free analysis. I also have experience with SILAC and AQUA peptides. During my Ph.D., I worked extensively with in-gel digestion of coomassie-stained bands for proteins/protein complexes identification, and protein N-terminal enrichment by ChaFRADIC (variation of COFRADIC) and developed novel methods for better proteome coverage. Name: Maisa Lima
Title: Greater Sacramento
Location: Chemist | R&D | Researcher at University of California
About: Chemist with a multidisciplinary background with +12 years of experience; Lic. Sc. (2013) and B.Sc. (2015) in Chemistry focusing on Analytical and Environmental Chemistry, M.Sc. in Agrochemistry (2015) focusing on Analytical Chemistry and Ph.D. in Chemistry (2019) focusing on Inorganic Chemistry at the Federal University of Lavras (UFLA), Brazil. After completing her PhD in Chemistry, she transitioned to a career in Wine Chemistry. She works as a researcher at the Robert Mondavi Institute for Wine and Food Science at the University of California, Davis, focusing on juice chemistry of Bordeaux grape varieties (Merlot, Cabernet sauvignon, Cabernet franc and Petit Verdot) from Napa Valley, California, USA and Bolgheri, Tuscany, Italy and Pinot noir wines from California and Oregon, USA. The projects have the goal of elucidating site contributions to wine chemistry. She works to develop the methods to analyze amino acids, biogenic amines, organic acids, sugars and vitamins in red wines and grape juices on the HPLC-DAD, UHPLC-FLD/RID, LC-MS/MS. Besides that, she works with the analysis of phenolic compounds on the HPLC-DAD and volatile aroma compounds on the HS-SPME/GC-MS in Pinot noir wines from fifteen vineyards sites from Oregon to Southern California, USA. Currently, her interests involve Wine Chemistry, Environmental Chemistry and Catalysis.Wine Chemistry | Green Chemistry | CatalysisChemist with a multidisciplinary background with +12 years of experience; Lic. Name: Maggie Fink
Title: South Bend, Indiana, United States
Location: PhD Candidate | Science Communicator | Artist | Author
About: Maggie Fink is an award-winning scientist, poet, and illustrator. Maggie received her bachelor’s degree in biochemistry from Indiana University South Bend and a bachelor’s in theology from Northland International University. She is currently a PhD student at the University of Notre Dame studying how bacteria talk to each other on the molecular level. Maggie has received multiple awards for her scientific research. In 2021, she was recognized with the prestigious National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship Award. She has also received the Joseph Ross Science Presentation award, a National Science Foundation Research Experience for Undergraduates Award, and the Carolyn and Lawrence Garber Research Fellowship. Her work has appeared in journals such as Protein Engineering Design and Selection and was presented at several national and regional scientific conferences. Maggie is also a co-inventor on a United States patent application for using proteins to detect the herbicide found in RoundUp in soil and drinking water. Maggie is a strong advocate for women in science, serving as a mentor for the Association of Women in Science (AWIS) and as a member of the Committee of Women Faculty and Students as well as the Leadership Advancing Socially Engaging Research (LASER). For her work, Maggie received the Indiana University Women Helping Women Award, and was appointed as the Campus Lead Peer Mentor. As a writer, Maggie’s poetry appeared in Landlocked Lyres and received the award for Best Creative Writing at the Annual Indiana University South Bend Conference on Undergraduate Research and Creative Activities. In addition to her writing, she has also been recognized for her illustrative work and is known for incorporating her art into her scientific presentations. She is also engaged in science communication efforts locally and nationally. She participated in the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology “Art of Science Communication” workshop and presented her work at the Annual Indiana Science Communication Day.Maggie Fink is an award-winning scientist, poet, and illustrator. Name: Igor Westphal
Title: Houston, Texas, United States
Location: PhD researcher in Economics with a keen interest in electricity markets.
About: I am a fifth year Economics PhD researcher at the Rice University School of Social Sciences. I am interested in Energy Economics and, in particular, electricity markets. Over the course of my PhD, I have acquired solid knowledge of computational economics, econometrics and statistical modelling, along with knowledge about complex regulatory issues present in wholesale electricity markets. My research mostly deals with studying economic challenges posed by renewable power sources and how to overcome them through alternative public policy. I have experience in translating large, raw and complex energy datasets into meaningful insights, and communicating them in a clear and concise way. Prior to moving to Texas, I majored in Mechanical Engineering and obtained a Masters degree in Economics. I am excited to hear about research and job opportunities! I can be reached at iw6@rice.edu.I am a fifth year Economics PhD researcher at the Rice University School of Social Sciences. Name: Jeffrey DuBose
Title: Pasadena, California, United States
Location: Postdoctoral Researcher at Caltech
About: Jeff is currently a postdoctoral researcher at Caltech, advised by Karthish Manthiram. Broadly, he is interested in the photo-, electro-, and nano-chemistry of renewable energy materials and systems. His current research focuses on understanding the electrode-microbe interface using advanced microscopy techniques.Jeff's previous postdoc research at the University of Notre Dame Radiation Laboratory centered on understanding the photochemistry of organic semiconductors used in light energy conversion. There he obtained expertise in pulse radiolysis techniques unique to the Notre Dame Radiation Lab.Jeff's PhD research focused on a class of renewable energy materials called halide perovskites, with the overall aim to design and improve light-harvesting materials for photovoltaics (solar cells) and photocatalysis (driving chemical reactions with light). He studied energy and charge transfer events occurring in bulk and nanoscale materials using time-resolved spectroscopy and electrochemical techniques. Name: Josephine Sarpong Akosa
Title: South Bend, Indiana, United States
Location: Researcher | Experienced Data Scientist | Statistician | Data Enthusiast
About: I am currently a Research Assistant Professor of IT, Analytics, and Operations in the Mendoza College of Business at the University of Notre Dame. My research interest is in high-dimensional statistical inference. Rapid advancement in technology has allowed an accelerated increase in the amount of data collected in many research fields, thereby allowing for thousands or millions of null hypotheses to be tested simultaneously with a relatively small number of experimental units. The general characteristics associated with such inferential problems are: 1) the dimension of the data is much larger than the sample size, 2) there is complex, mostly uncharacterized dependencies among the variables under consideration, 3) error rates are inflated due to simultaneous hypotheses testing, and 4) some of the null hypotheses are expected to be true. Traditional methods for simultaneous inference are designed in the realm of independent and normally distributed data with the number of samples being larger than the dimension of the data, when in fact these are not the general characteristics of high-dimensional inferential problems. Thus, there is a need to develop multiple testing procedures that exploit the general characteristics of high-dimensional data. I focus on developing powerful multiple comparison procedures for non-normally distributed data that incorporate small sample adaptations to estimation procedures of the model parameters. I have also worked on projects involving imbalanced data modeling. Most importantly, I have had great exposure to analyzing and building predictive models on really messy and ''ugly'' high-dimensional real life data. My goal is to work with hardworking and talented individuals within the research or business industry to address some of the world's greatest challenges. For more information about me, please visit my web page at https://sites.google.com/site/jsakosa/ or https://mendoza.nd.edu/mendoza-directory/profile/?slug=josephine-akosaI am currently a Research Assistant Professor of IT, Analytics, and Operations in the Mendoza College of Business at the University of Notre Dame. Name: Flavio C.
Title: Greater Boston
Location: Assistant Professor at Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences
About: I am currently an Assistant Professor at Harvard University. Before joining Harvard, I was a Social Good Post-Doctoral Fellow at the IBM T.J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, New York. I received my Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department at MIT in the Summer of 2015. My main research interests are information theory, inference and statistics, with applications to security, privacy, machine learning and content distribution. You can find more details on my personal website.My current research has three intertwined goals: (i) develop theory and models that capture the fundamental limits of estimation and learning from data, (ii) construct learning, fairness, security and privacy mechanisms with performance guarantees based on these limits, and (iii) use this methodology as a design driver for future information processing and content distribution systems. In order to achieve these goals, I draw from the fields of information theory, statistics, cryptography and machine learning. I seek to develop tools that will guide the design of systems that acquire, process and distribute information while providing reliability, efficiency, and privacy guarantees.I am currently an Assistant Professor at Harvard University. Name: Guilherme Mendes Resende
Title: Federal District, Brazil
Location: Economista-chefe do CADE
About: É PhD em economia regional pela London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE) e mestre em economia pela Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais-UFMG. Possui graduação em economia, direito e administração de empresas. É pesquisador concursado do Instituto de Pesquisa Econômica Aplicada (IPEA) desde 2004. Desde 2016, é economista-chefe do Conselho Administrativo de Defesa da Concorrência (CADE). Desde 2019, é professor no Mestrado de Economia do Instituto Brasilense de Direito Público (IDP). Entre 2015-2016, foi diretor-adjunto da Diretoria de Estudos Regionais, Urbanos e Ambientais (DIRUR/IPEA). Foi Coordenador de Estudos Regionais da DIRUR/IPEA entre 2013-2014. Tem experiência na área métodos quantitativos, economia da concorrência, avaliação de políticas públicas e desenvolvimento regional e urbano, tendo vários trabalhos publicados em revistas acadêmicas nacionais e internacionais. Foi ganhador de vários prêmios nacionais e internacionais, entre eles o Prêmio INFI-FEBRABAN de Economia Bancária de 2015, o Prêmio BNB de Economia Regional 2015, o Prêmio SBE Finanças 2015 (2º lugar), o Prêmio Paulo Haddad 2011 da Associação Brasileira de Estudos Regionais e Urbanos e o Prêmio Epainos 2009 da Associação Européia de Ciência Regional (ERSA). Possui mais de 80 trabalhos publicados no Brasil e no exterior.É PhD em economia regional pela London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE) e mestre em economia pela Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais-UFMG. Name: Anusha Kumar
Title: United States
Location: Scientist
About: I am a highly passionate and experienced protein chemist skilled in high-throughput combinatorial research platform, biophysical characterization of proteins, and formulation development.Despite the long known importance of biophysical characterization in monitoring protein stability, there are several challenges that make it hard to implement these techniques to develop a pharmaceutical product. My interest lies in developing high-throughput biophysical methods that can be used in screening multiple formulations in a short time as well as to study the correlation between biophysical parameters to long term protein stability.I have 6+ years of experience in designing combinatorial research libraries and studying the sequence-stability relationships in four-helix bundles. This has resulted in multiple presentations including in Gordon and ACS conferences. I also have expertise in working with large sets of sequencing data which made me obtain interesting patterns of functional folds in four-helix bundles. My interest and passion in protein stability methods has helped me acquire a lot of skills which include DSC, CD, DSF, DLS, MALS, SPR, CE, MALDI, ESI MS. I have also acquired skills of working with different formulations using DOE in JMP. Name: Coleson Weir
Title: Newark, Delaware, United States
Location: PhD Student in Economics at Notre Dame
About: I am a doctoral student in the Department of Economics at the University of Notre Dame. In addition, I am a PhD Fellow at the Kellogg Institute for International Studies at Notre Dame. My current research interests are in development economics, political economy, and public economics; I want to look at how government institutions and laws affect the wellbeing of people. Prior to Notre Dame, I was graduated from the University of Delaware where I simultaneously completed my Master of Science degree in Economics and Applied Econometrics and my Honors Bachelor of Science degree in Mathematics and Economics with minors in Political Science and Theatre Studies. At the University of Delaware, I completed research at on the effect of health laws on education levels in Benin in the Department of Economics. In the Department of Mathematical Sciences, I conducted research at the intersection of probability theory and combinatorics to look at the mixing time of Markov chains on robotic arms in tunnels of width m. Name: Ana Karina de Oliveira
Title: Charlottesville, Virginia, United States
Location: Director of Spatial Biology Core 🔬🧫
About: I am an Assistant Professor at the Department of Pathology and Director of the Spatial Biology Core (SBC) at the University of Virginia School of Medicine, USA.The Core Facility has a mission of supporting the scientific community of UVA and outside grounds to access the cute edge technology in Spatial Omics Analysis.Our Core supports research by offering services such as:*Scientific Support*Sample Preparation*Data Analysis*Confocal and Non-Confocal microscopy services (Operetta® CLS™ a high throughput microplate imager for high-content analysis); *Single-Cell Secretome Analysis (Isoplexis); *ChipCytometry Multiplex Analysis with a Single-Cell Resolution Image (Zellscanner - Canopy Biosciences); *Multiplex Analysis in a bulk solution (nCounter - NanoString Technologies); *Spatial Omics Analysis (GeoMx DSP - Nanostring Technologies) that combines immunofluorescence techniques with digital Barcoding Technology and RNA sequence.My research interest focuses on identifying candidates as human cancer markers using mainly spatial transcriptomics, proteomics, and immune phenotyping approaches. I am also interested in studying the molecular mechanisms involved in immune evasion, cancer development (breast precancer lesion), and progression, using in vitro and in vivo models. My long-term career aspirations focus on finding new molecular targets for breast cancer therapeutic prevention and predicting and guiding immunotherapeutic responsiveness in cancer patients.I am an Assistant Professor at the Department of Pathology and Director of the Spatial Biology Core (SBC) at the University of Virginia School of Medicine, USA. Name: Hadi Kiapour
Title: San Francisco, California, United States
Location: Computer Vision
About: A technical leader with strong background in AI, particularly computer vision and deep learning. I lead the computer vision group at Dawnlight, founded by world–renowned AI pioneers), working on the next generation of ambient intelligence using machine learning. We build video based human activity and object recognition systems for real-time processing on edge computers. Previously I was a researcher at eBay, where I developed deep learning models for large scale product recognition and visual search. I have experience in hiring and building diverse and effective teams, and tackling fundamental and applied research problems to bridge the gap between academia and industry. I am passionate about delivering scalable AI solutions that reach the public.I’m interested in all aspects of multi-modal computer vision and deep learning. My interests include efficient deep learning, action recognition, pose estimation, multimodal vision, semantic segmentation, object detection, image-text embeddings, large scale visual search and fine-grained classification.I completed my PhD in 2015 and have published 30+ papers and patents with 2000+ citations in premier conferences and journals including TPAMI, ACM Multimedia, CVPR, ICCV, ECCV. Name: Wendson Barbosa
Title: Columbus, Ohio Metropolitan Area
Location: Postdoctoral Researcher in Physics at The Ohio State University
About: I am postdoctoral researcher at The Ohio State University with Ph.D. in Physics and experience in machine learning. From my graduate studies I have a background in nonlinear dynamics, chaos and optics. For the past three years, I have been using my nonlinear dynamics expertise in multiple machine-learning-related projects that have different stakeholders and collaboration teams (different research groups from other universities). My research has been focused in investigating fundamental properties of machine learning algorithms and developing related approaches to high-efficiently solve problems like, for example, dynamical systems prediction and pattern recognition. I make a point of saying I fell in love with the Machine Learning world. Is not it amazing how it can address and solve the most different kind of data-based problems, from the most fundamental classification to a very complex real world system prediction? I am proud to say that I am always learning!I am postdoctoral researcher at The Ohio State University with Ph.D. in Physics and experience in machine learning. Name: Julia Castro
Title: United States
Location: Architect and Urbanist | Project manager at Trívia Arquitetura
About: I am an architect and urbanist graduated from the University of Brasília in 2022. In addition to my passion for architecture, I am very interested in communication. My experiences in other areas could help me to further develop my creativity and to become an interdisciplinary professional, that can provide more innovative solutions. I constantly challenge myself with the creation possibilities in the field of architecture, that are now integrating other languages, tools, and technologies, by exploring new design processes. My ambition is to be part of the change in architecture’s identity in the world, especially in Brazil, by integrating all forms of technology and hybridizing the analogical to the virtual. I aspire to become a reference in interactive and human-centric architecture, investigating new forms of design and digital technologies that can stimulate emotions with immersive installations and interactive experiences. Name: Francisco Martins
Title: St Paul, Minnesota, United States
Location: Postdoctoral | Researcher | Chemist. I am a problem-solving, eager learner, and very curious about nature.
About: Hello everyone, welcome! Feel free to interact. I have been working with molecular modeling since 2014. Notably, computational tools are widely employed to solve problems in any field, such as pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and materials. It is not different in chemistry/biochemistry. Simulating systems and processes in a computer can be very cheap and fast, avoiding unnecessary cost and time, an essential feature for any company. My professional history began much earlier than my acceptance in an undergraduate course. I worked in quite different jobs. I worked as a ball boy (on the tennis court), a waiter, a machine operator, and a production assistant. I found myself when I started a chemistry course and started working as an undergraduate researcher in 2014. After that, I got a master's degree in science. Now, I am a Ph.D.(Universidade Federal de Lavras (UFLA), Brazil).My main focus is organic chemistry, but I am also passionate about biochemistry/biology. Although my primary focus is molecular modeling, I also have experience in the wet lab. During my Ph.D., I performed synthesis, infrared (IR), and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) analysis. I also started studying drug discovery and how this optimization can be done using computational tools such as molecular docking and quantitative structure-activity relationship (QSAR). My professional life demonstrates that I am very comfortable learning different things in different areas. I like the challenge, and I see every situation as an opportunity to obtain more knowledge.I got a basic level in German and Italian. Name: XIANG DENG
Title: Columbus, Ohio, United States
Location: Ph.D. Candidate at The Ohio State University
About: My research interests lie in NLP and data mining, with emphasis on knowledge discovery and utilization from heterogeneous sources. The aim is to build AI-powered data systems that can assist with information acquisition and decision making for regular users as well as domain experts in Digital Era. Specifically, I am exploring the following directions:1. Large-scale pretraining and representation learning for data from heterogeneous sources, e.g., web texts and tables, knowledge graphs, and databases; both for general and domain-specific applications2. Name: André Victor Oliveira Avellar
Title: Evanston, Illinois, United States
Location: Incoming student at Northwestern University (26’) | Fellow @ Fundação Estudar
About: Holding a diploma as a Pharmacy Technician from the Federal Institute of Rio de Janeiro, André is from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, and an incoming first-year student at Northwestern University, where he intends to double-major in Biological Science - concentration in Biochemistry - and Global Health. During his high school, he got deeply involved in developing scientific projects that aimed to develop alternative treatments for hospital acquired infections and chronic diseases (hypertension and diabetes, especially) in renowned lab centers and researchers. This led him to publish articles, summaries and win over 25 prizes and institutions recognitions, including from the Brazilian Biochemistry and Microbiology Society, and his participation at Regeneron ISEF, the largest science fair for pre-college students in the world. Passionate by scientific education, during the pandemic, André helped the Brazilian Association for Science Promotion to develop the “30 days of science” program, rescuing the interest of 50+ students in scientific methodology and projects’ development, besides tutoring students who are enthusiastic about chemistry. By developing student’s skills in writing articles, summaries, communication, chemistry, André gathers over 10 national and international prizes as a project mentor. Therefore, André is willing to help mentees develop themselves, including any skill sets that you are effective at teaching, such as time management, becoming more action oriented, learning to set goals, etc.Furthermore, André had already been a chemistry tutor in his school helping high school and undergraduate students increase their yield in Inorganic and General Chemistry as well as in scientific olympiads, in which André has 10+ recognitions. About: I am an Adjunct Professor in Genetics and Forest Tree Breeding at the Central-West State University (UNICENTRO), Brazil. I am also an advisor for the graduate program in Forest Science at the Paulista State University (Unesp) and Forest Resources at ESALQ/USP. I teach in the area of Genetics and Forest Improvement integrating traditional quantitative genetic tools with genomic selection. I am interested in training undergraduate and graduate students to work in industry, research institutes, and universities to maximize the genetic gains in improvement programs in the forestry sector, understand and propose genetic conservation strategies for Pinus and Eucalyptus, and develop more accurate statistics on the various components of genetic variance for species with a mixed mating system. Name: Ruben Glatt
Title: Livermore, California, United States

About: With a background in Mechatronics and Mechanical Engineering, Ruben has turned to Artificial Intelligence where his main interest lies in Machine Learning (ML) research with a focus on Reinforcement Learning (RL), autonomous systems, and applications in energy efficiency.He received his Ph.D. in Computer Engineering in the area of ML at the University of São Paulo (USP), Brazil, holds a master degree in Mechanical Engineering in the area of controlling mechanical systems from the Universidade Estadual Paulista Júlio de Mesquita Filho(UNESP), Brazil, and a Diplom-Ingenieur degree in Mechatronics in the area of sensors and robotics from the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT), Germany.Ruben has acquired years of professional experience before and during his studies while working in the technology and energy sector, as well as in the organization of international ML conferences. After converting from a postdoctoral position at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, USA, he is now working as a Machine Learning Researcher on a variety of RL projects to develop methods for collaborative autonomy in multi-agent systems, interpretable RL, and real-world applications. Ruben also acts as the chair of the Lawrence Livermore Postdoc Association and represents the Lab’s postdocs in the Institutional Postdoc Program Board.Ruben’s long-term research interest lies in successfully applying RL techniques to real-world challenges to accelerate and improve decision-making, autonomously or as a support tool for humans, preferably for applications in energy and smart mobility systems.With a background in Mechatronics and Mechanical Engineering, Ruben has turned to Artificial Intelligence where his main interest lies in Machine Learning (ML) research with a focus on Reinforcement Learning (RL), autonomous systems, and applications in energy efficiency. He received his Ph.D. in Computer Engineering in the area of ML at the University of São Paulo (USP), Brazil, holds a master degree in Mechanical Engineering in the area of controlling mechanical systems from the Universidade Estadual Paulista Júlio de Mesquita Filho(UNESP), Brazil, and a Diplom-Ingenieur degree in Mechatronics in the area of sensors and robotics from the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT), Germany. Ruben has acquired years of professional experience before and during his studies while working in the technology and energy sector, as well as in the organization of international ML conferences. After converting from a postdoctoral position at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, USA, he is now working as a Machine Learning Researcher on a variety of RL projects to develop methods for collaborative autonomy in multi-agent systems, interpretable RL, and real-world applications. Ruben also acts as the chair of the Lawrence Livermore Postdoc Association and represents the Lab’s postdocs in the Institutional Postdoc Program Board. Ruben’s long-term research interest lies in successfully applying RL techniques to real-world challenges to accelerate and improve decision-making, autonomously or as a support tool for humans, preferably for applications in energy and smart mobility systems.

Name: Victor Rafael R. Celestino
Title: Federal District, Brazil
Location: Professor Adjunto na UnB
About: Professor Adjunto na Universidade de Brasília (UnB) no Departamento de Administração da Faculdade de Economia, Administração, Contabilidade e Gestão Pública (ADM/FACE). Graduação em Engenharia Aeronáutica no Instituto Tecnológico de Aeronáutica (ITA), Mestre em Métodos Quantitativos (ITA), Doutor em Psicologia na Universidade Católica de Brasília (UCB). Especialista em Regulação da Aviação Civil (ANAC), em Estratégia Organizacional (FGV) e Engenharia de Ensaios em Voo (DCTA), além de diversos cursos de educação continuada. Possui formação em diversas práticas integrativas e complementares (PICS) em saúde, entre essas, constelações sistêmicas familiares e organizacionais, meditação e yoga. Com mais de trinta e cinco anos de experiência profissional, atuou em diversos ambientes organizacionais, inclusive na gestão organizacional e na direção estratégica, no setor público e em empresas nacionais e multinacionais. Vinte anos de experiência na docência na graduação e pós-graduação. Extensa experiência internacional. Ensino de Análise de Decisões e Métodos e Modelos Quantitativos para a Tomada de Decisão. Pesquisa com foco no Setor Aeroespacial, em CT&I, em Finanças e Organizações e nos Fatores Humanos no Trabalho. Ensino e Pesquisa com aplicação de Métodos Quantitativos, Ciência de Dados e Inteligência Artificial. Fluência em Inglês, e bons conhecimentos de Espanhol, Francês e Alemão. Name: Chibueze Oguejiofor
Title: Notre Dame, Indiana, United States
Location: ASP Graduate Visiting Fellow at NCAR - The National Center for Atmospheric Research | PhD Student
About: I am a PhD researcher at the University of Notre Dame, working on modeling the dynamics of hurricane rapid intensification (RI). I joined the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR), as an advanced study (ASP) graduate visitor in Fall 2022. My research focusses on utilizing a combination of numerical weather models (WRF) and large eddy simulations (LES), insitu observation dataset and satellite data sources to systematically probe the influence of surface heterogeneities on the rapid intensification of tropical cyclones. I have extensive research experience in geostatistics and spatial-temporal modeling, analysis of gridded climate dataset, machine learning and cloud computing. Computational skills include the use of Fortran, NCL, Python, MATLAB, SQL, R and HPC platforms for climate model runs etc.https://chibueze-oguejiofor.github.io/I am a PhD researcher at the University of Notre Dame, working on modeling the dynamics of hurricane rapid intensification (RI). Name: Eric Goldwyn
Title: New York, New York, United States
Location: NYU Marron | TransitCosts.com
About: I am currently working on a research project on transit-infrastructure costs with Alon Levy and Elif Ensari at NYU's Marron Institute of Urban Management. We hope to understand why costs vary from country to country, what drives costs, and develop best practices for high-cost countries to adopt so that they can build more transit for each dollar spent. Check out our website: transitcosts.com I am also working with Sound Transit's Technical Advisory Group to explore ways to accelerate project-delivery schedule and contain costs of Sound Transit's $53.8 billion system-expansion plan, ST3. In July 2021, Sound Transit determined that increasing costs have made the current plan unaffordable and seeks to close an estimated $6.5 billion net shortfall.I also teach courses at NYU on urban studies. Courses tend to take a historical approach to cities to understand how things have changed and what the future may look like.I often write things about cities and transport. Name: Pedro Vormittag
Title: New York, New York, United States
Location: Columbia SIPA | FGV-EAESP | University of São Paulo | Researcher & Writer | Sustainable Development & Human Rights
About: 5 THINGS ABOUT ME1. I'm a Researcher. That's what I've been doing for years on topics like management strategy, social innovation, climate change, geopolitics, clean energy, human rights, and for all kinds of audiences — from government officials, bankers, lawyers, undergraduates, to journalists and their readers, bosses, peers, or employees!2. I love — love! — writing. I don't care if it's a 50-page report that will guide students in a lecture by a Nobel laureate, a policy brief about solar energy in the Amazon for a Minister, or if it's a speech for myself or someone running for office. I also do love reasonable deadlines, but let's face it: those are rare, and time pressure doesn't always have to be the enemy of excellence!3. Sustainable development is my passion. Conversations about climate change (SDG 13), energy transition (SDG 7), and biodiversity (SDG 14, 15) will always get my attention. In my past, I'm proud to have delved into the challenges of creating policies for homeless people (SDG 11) and imprisoned people (SDG 16), as well as sports and leisure policies for older adults (SDG 3), and to have been vocal on the agenda for public education (SDG 4).4. I am interdisciplinary. After all, if someone graduates from Law School, but goes to work with social policy in government, then jumps into a Master's in management & business and lands at Columbia to study energy and climate, I've got to be able to find connections among complex areas — and take pleasure in pitching them to people!5. Speaking of people, I take pride in having dealt with people from the most different backgrounds, values, and expertise in my professional life. Getting a project done is even more exciting when it is the collective product of stakeholders with competing interests (e.g., opposing political parties), leaders from different cultures (e.g., Latin American, Chinese and New Yorkers!), or colleagues with diversified talents (e.g. engineers, lawyers and a soccer players!)5 THINGS ABOUT ME 1. Name: Sugat Dabholkar
Title: Chicago, Illinois, United States
Location: Learning Sciences Researcher
About: I am a researcher in the field of Learning Science. I study how people learn and how learning environments can be designed to enable specific kinds of learning experiences.I did my PhD in the Learning Sciences program at the Northwestern University. I worked as a distinguished research fellow at School of Education and Social Policy at Northwestern and taught undergraduate Learning Sciences courses at Northwestern. I am currently working at Rutgers University as a postdoc to study how justice-centered community-based science curriculum can be designed for middle school students and how such curricula can support student participation is doing and learning science in community contexts.I am keenly interested in understanding how people navigate their relationships with knowledge in various disciplinary domains. I am interested in questions like how do their roles in their relationships with knowledge shift as recipients, as evaluators, as producers of knowledge? How do they see participation in a disciplinary domain for themselves and for practitioners of that domain? I study how specific designs of learning environments can support learners navigate their agency in various knowledge domains.I am a researcher in the field of Learning Science. I'm doing this by using engineered protein polymers developed in our lab to clump proteins and RNA together and turn genes on or off. In addition, I'm a Lead Associate with Duke Capital Partners, focusing on the life sciences part of our operations, where I source, screen, and conduct diligence on companies with Duke connections. Name: Dr. Rachel Burstein
Title: San Francisco Bay Area
Location: Education Researcher & Writer
About: I am a researcher and writer with experience in the education, edtech, social studies, and civic innovation spaces. My sweet spot is small-scale qualitative research projects with storytelling elements that inspire change. Sound interesting to you? Let’s talk! Learn more about my approach and services at www.bursteinresearch.com.What makes me tick? Throughout my career, I’ve been guided by the following values and beliefs:Rigorous qualitative research leads with good questions. - I see qualitative research as a tool of discovery rather than a way of confirming existing policies, beliefs, biases, and ideas. We need to make sure that we’re asking worthy questions, adopting methodologies that allow us to examine those questions, and listening to what diverse research participants tell us. Research should be a tool for lifting up the priorities of the communities that we aim to serve. - I believe that we need to design research questions and studies in ways that provide opportunities for vulnerable members of our community to inform and co-develop policies, programs, and tools.Complex ideas ought to be accessible to everyone. - I view framing, sensitivity, and the belief in the intellectual curiosity and capacity of all as vitally important. As a researcher, writer, teacher, and curriculum designer, I’ve seen how respectful presentation of complex ideas can transform lives.Quality and expertise matter. - I’ve seen how teams comprised of people with different areas of expertise can work collaboratively to create policies and products that are transformational for teachers and learners. I’ve also seen how deprioritizing quality shortchanges students and educators.Stories can be powerful agents of change. But ultimately it is policy that matters. - I believe that research can uncover powerful stories that can help make the case for change in educational policy and practice. But I also firmly believe that policies need to change in substantial ways if we are to make deep change in service of students and educators.I am a researcher and writer with experience in the education, edtech, social studies, and civic innovation spaces. My sweet spot is small-scale qualitative research projects with storytelling elements that inspire change. Sound interesting to you? Let’s talk! Complex ideas ought to be accessible to everyone. - I view framing, sensitivity, and the belief in the intellectual curiosity and capacity of all as vitally important. As a researcher, writer, teacher, and curriculum designer, I’ve seen how respectful presentation of complex ideas can transform lives. Quality and expertise matter. - I’ve seen how teams comprised of people with different areas of expertise can work collaboratively to create policies and products that are transformational for teachers and learners. I’ve also seen how deprioritizing quality shortchanges students and educators. Stories can be powerful agents of change. But ultimately it is policy that matters. - I believe that research can uncover powerful stories that can help make the case for change in educational policy and practice. But I also firmly believe that policies need to change in substantial ways if we are to make deep change in service of students and educators.

Research should be a tool for lifting up the priorities of the communities that we aim to serve. - I believe that we need to design research questions and studies in ways that provide opportunities for vulnerable members of our community to inform and co-develop policies, programs, and tools.Complex ideas ought to be accessible to everyone. - I view framing, sensitivity, and the belief in the intellectual curiosity and capacity of all as vitally important. As a researcher, writer, teacher, and curriculum designer, I’ve seen how respectful presentation of complex ideas can transform lives.Quality and expertise matter. - I’ve seen how teams comprised of people with different areas of expertise can work collaboratively to create policies and products that are transformational for teachers and learners. I’ve also seen how deprioritizing quality shortchanges students and educators.Stories can be powerful agents of change. But ultimately it is policy that matters. - I believe that research can uncover powerful stories that can help make the case for change in educational policy and practice. But I also firmly believe that policies need to change in substantial ways if we are to make deep change in service of students and educators.I am a researcher and writer with experience in the education, edtech, social studies, and civic innovation spaces. My sweet spot is small-scale qualitative research projects with storytelling elements that inspire change. Sound interesting to you? Let’s talk! Name: Jose Roberto Ayala Solares
Title: Seattle, Washington, United States
Location: Research Scientist at Amazon
About: I'm a passionately curious researcher and traveler. Ever since I got my BSc in Mechatronics Engineering in Mexico, I've been pursuing a journey of learning and personal growth that has taken me to live in 7 countries and visited a total of 51 so far.I lived for two years in the sandy lands of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, where I got an MSc in Applied Mathematics and Computational Science. There I worked on some research projects related to simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM), and wireless sensor networks in cognitive radio regimes.After that, I went back to Mexico, where I lectured for a few months in my alma mater. My main responsibilities were teaching engineering courses focusing on Python for robotics, numerical methods in MATLAB, and control engineering.Later on, I got interested in machine learning and decided to fly across the Atlantic Ocean again to pursue a Ph.D. from the Department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering at The University Of Sheffield in the United Kingdom. My research focused on modeling and analysis of environmental systems using machine learning, data mining, and system identification techniques. During those years, I self-taught myself R, and all my research was developed in this programming language.Once I got my Ph.D., I worked as a Machine Learning Scientist at the George Institute for Global Health at the University of Oxford. There I employed and developed machine and deep learning algorithms that could find patterns in large multi-modal data for managing some of the healthcare challenges facing the world in the 21st century.Some years ago, I decided to move away from academia and give it a go in industry. I currently work for Amazon in the United States. My main work consists of building mathematical models for demand forecasting of Amazon devices.When I'm not working (from home), I'm learning something new, improving my coding skills, watching documentaries, reading fantasy/sci-fi/science, exploring the city I'm currently living at, or planning my next trip.I'm a passionately curious researcher and traveler. Ever since I got my BSc in Mechatronics Engineering in Mexico, I've been pursuing a journey of learning and personal growth that has taken me to live in 7 countries and visited a total of 51 so far. I lived for two years in the sandy lands of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, where I got an MSc in Applied Mathematics and Computational Science. There I worked on some research projects related to simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM), and wireless sensor networks in cognitive radio regimes. After that, I went back to Mexico, where I lectured for a few months in my alma mater. My main responsibilities were teaching engineering courses focusing on Python for robotics, numerical methods in MATLAB, and control engineering. Later on, I got interested in machine learning and decided to fly across the Atlantic Ocean again to pursue a Ph.D. from the Department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering at The University Of Sheffield in the United Kingdom. My main work consists of building mathematical models for demand forecasting of Amazon devices. Name: Paulo Strazza Junior
Title: Portland, Oregon, United States
Location: Neuroscientist | MSc in Physiology
About: Hello and welcome!I'm a neuroscientist trained in both biological and exact sciences, captivated by combined experimental and theoretical approaches in scientific research. I hold a BSc in Biological Sciences and a MSc in Physiology, both from the University of São Paulo (USP). I’ve done my master at the laboratory of Neurophysiology and Synapse, at the Ribeirão Preto Medical School (FMRP), where I investigated how subthreshold conductances (or different types of ion channels) control the diverse firing patterns of brainstem neurons. After completing the master, I started a second BSc in Computational Physics at the São Carlos Institute of Physics (IFSC-USP), and in the meantime, I was offered a Senior Research Assistant position at the Vollum Institute (Oregon Health & Science University | OHSU, Portland, OR). At the von Gersdorff Lab, my research has been mainly about the neurotransmission between neurons comprising the retinal cross-over inhibitory circuit. So far, I've been working in the Neuronal Electrophysiology field, but I'm intending to also do research in Theoretical & Computational Neuroscience in the near future, specially on the biophysical mechanisms underlying neuronal computations and information processing.➡️ My long term goal is to contribute to a better understanding of how large scale neuroactivity (and ultimatelly behavior) depends on synaptic and biophysical properties of brain circuits and neurons.ORCID: http://orcid.org/0000-0001-9957-4212 Lattes: http://lattes.cnpq.br/1022768535795196💡 Some of my "outside lab" favorite themes are: - Science Popularization & History of Science- Neurobiology of Homeostasis and Neurobiology of Consciousness (e.g. Christof Koch) - Psychoneuroimmunology & the Placebo Effect (e.g. Frabrizio Benedetti)- Evolution of brains and minds- Behavioral Genetics & Nature-Nurture interplay- Systems Biology & Origins of Life- Biomathematics & Biostatistics- Research on Spirituality & Health (e.g. ProSER IPq-USP, Nupes-UFJF).Hello and welcome! I'm a neuroscientist trained in both biological and exact sciences, captivated by combined experimental and theoretical approaches in scientific research. Name: Marco Ataide
Title: San Francisco, California, United States
Location: Scientist (Inflammation)
About: Experimental Immunologist.Topics of interest: Inflammation, Immunotherapy, Immuno-oncology, CD8+ T and unconventional T cells immunobiology, Chimeric Antigen Receptors Modified CAR-T/NK cells, and basic Innate and Adaptive ImmunobiologyI have been focusing my research on the fundamental questions of how the immune system operates at a cellular and molecular level in steady-state and under pathogen-induced inflammation.I classify myself as an experimental immunologist with substantial hands-on in vivo and in vitro experimental settings. I have developed in-depth knowledge and practical skills in cutting-edge technologies, such as Multi-parametric Flow Cytometry (classical and spectrum analyzers), Single-Cell Sequencing Analysis (scRNAseq), and Microscopy (confocal and intravital imaging). I also had the chance to guide and train several students at different levels during all of these years working in academia.I have been working with different types of cells (in vitro and in vivo). However, I have a particular passion for T-cell-based immune responses. I have had a remarkable chance to assess a piece of the molecular network controlling the in vivo development of memory CD8 T cells. In this study, which was published in Nature Immunology (2020), I have found that the transcription factor BATF3 programs CD8 T cell memory opening up a new opportunity for T cell engineering to fight cancer.Another important study that came out of my postdoctoral training, deals with novel concepts in unconventional T cells (UTC) immunobiology, where we show how UTC promotes site-specific immunity in different lymph nodes ( Immunity in press, 2022 )Complete publication list: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/?term=ataide+maExperimental Immunologist. Topics of interest: Inflammation, Immunotherapy, Immuno-oncology, CD8+ T and unconventional T cells immunobiology, Chimeric Antigen Receptors Modified CAR-T/NK cells, and basic Innate and Adaptive Immunobiology I have been focusing my research on the fundamental questions of how the immune system operates at a cellular and molecular level in steady-state and under pathogen-induced inflammation. I classify myself as an experimental immunologist with substantial hands-on in vivo and in vitro experimental settings. I have developed in-depth knowledge and practical skills in cutting-edge technologies, such as Multi-parametric Flow Cytometry (classical and spectrum analyzers), Single-Cell Sequencing Analysis (scRNAseq), and Microscopy (confocal and intravital imaging). I also had the chance to guide and train several students at different levels during all of these years working in academia. I have been working with different types of cells (in vitro and in vivo). However, I have a particular passion for T-cell-based immune responses. I have had a remarkable chance to assess a piece of the molecular network controlling the in vivo development of memory CD8 T cells. In this study, which was published in Nature Immunology (2020), I have found that the transcription factor BATF3 programs CD8 T cell memory opening up a new opportunity for T cell engineering to fight cancer. Another important study that came out of my postdoctoral training, deals with novel concepts in unconventional T cells (UTC) immunobiology, where we show how UTC promotes site-specific immunity in different lymph nodes ( Immunity in press, 2022 ) Complete publication list: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/?term=ataide+ma

Name: Javier Hernandez
Title: Boston, Massachusetts, United States
Location:
Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research, Research Affiliate at MIT Media Lab, 
Associate Editor at IEEE Transactions on Affective Computing
About: Javier Hernandez is a Principal Researcher at the Human Understanding and Empathy group of Microsoft Research, Research Affiliate at the Affective Computing group of the MIT Media Lab and Principal Investigator of the Emotional Navigation and Onsite Stress Measurement special interest groups. In addition, Javier is founder and CEO of Global Vitals LLC, an MIT Media Lab spin-off with the goal of democratizing physiological sensing.Javier’s research is focused on the development of emotionally intelligent tools to further the understanding of humans while fostering greater health and quality of life. In particular, Javier has made several contributions in the context of daily life stress and the use of technology to improve its measurement, understanding, and management. His work has been covered by a wide variety of media outlets such as National Geographic, The Economist, and The Times, and has received several recognitions such as MIT TR 35 and several best paper awards. He often provides guest lectures at MIT and other universities, and speaks at a wide variety of conferences and venues. Javier received a B.S in Computer Systems Engineering in 2004 and an M.S in Information Technology in 2007 at Ramon Llull University (Barcelona, Spain), an M.S. in Robotics and Artificial Intelligence in 2010 at Carnegie Mellon University (Pittsburgh, USA), and a Ph.D. in Media Arts and Science in 2015 at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Cambridge, USA).Javier Hernandez is a Principal Researcher at the Human Understanding and Empathy group of Microsoft Research, Research Affiliate at the Affective Computing group of the MIT Media Lab and Principal Investigator of the Emotional Navigation and Onsite Stress Measurement special interest groups. Name: Brian Kelleher Richter
Title: Austin, Texas, United States
Location: Applying Economic Analysis to Reveal Narratives in Data | Crafting Strategies Within & Beyond Markets | Bridging Business & Public Policy
About: I am an applied economist skilled at exposing accessible narratives in large datasets backed by rigorous analysis--with expertise at the intersections of business and public policy and experience in academia, government, finance and technology. This technical expertise, coupled with university and executive-level teaching experience, enables me to transform research insights into thought leadership and action plans that enable organizations to thrive. I thrive on cross-functional and multidisciplinary teams given the type of research I have conducted and given my work with different types of audiences.My research tends to be centered on causal inference and measurement work. I enjoy staying on the cutting edge of methods useful for the questions at hand. Approaches I have employed include: differences-in-differences (DiD), selection models, linear regression, instrumental variables, regression discontinuity designs (RDD), financial market event studies, synthetic control, Monte Carlo simulation/randomization inference, randomized A/B experiments, item response theory (IRT), geographic information systems (GIS), natural language processing (NLP), and off-the-shelf machine learning (ML) algorithms. I have applied these methods to datasets (many of which I have built) on lobbying, campaign contributions, notice-and-comment rulemaking, corporate political geography, and metrics of corporate social responsibility (CSR) / sustainability often merged with those on the market environment in which firms compete and on firm performance. Prior to earning my PhD, I worked in both public & private sectors (at technology firms & in finance), in the U.S. and internationally, including time with the Federal Reserve (in Washington DC & San Francisco), the Central Intelligence Agency (in Langley), the Japan External Trade Organization (in New York), the US Army Research Laboratory (in Adelphi, MD), Nomura Securities (in New York), Sanwa Bank (in Tokyo), Nokia (in Burlington, MA), ZEFER [a technology start-up] (in Boston), and The Motley Fool (in Alexandria, VA).I earned my PhD in Global Economics & Management from UCLA's Anderson School, an M.A. in Economics from UCLA, an M.P.I.A. in Asian Markets & Economies from UCSD's School of Global Policy & Strategy, and an S.B. in Management Science from MIT's Sloan School of Management. Currently, I am a professor at UT Austin's McCombs School of Business and a Senior Stigler Fellow at the University of Chicago's Booth School's Stigler Center for the Study of the Economy and State.I am an applied economist skilled at exposing accessible narratives in large datasets backed by rigorous analysis--with expertise at the intersections of business and public policy and experience in academia, government, finance and technology. Name: Dimitriy Masterov
Title: Oakland, California, United States
Location: Economist at Thumbtack
About: I am an empirical micro-economist. I am keenly interested in the business potential of modern econometric methods that integrate heterogeneity, diversity, and unobserved counterfactual states. These approaches ameliorate the problems caused by violations of standard statistical assumptions owing to the nature of economic relationships, and they facilitate the identification of true causal effects from the big data that today's companies have at their disposal. These are questions that A/B tests and predictive algorithms cannot always answer. I use these insights to inform features or policies to drive growth and build long-run value.But what does all that mean? I employ methods like panel data analysis, propensity score matching/re-weighting, instrumental variables, regression discontinuity, and synthetic cohort methods, and combine them with economic theory and causal ML techniques. These cutting edge tools allow me to provide answers to questions like what is the actual incremental effect on purchases from your shiny new mobile app. Because you can't just count the mobile transactions!Specialties: applied econometrics, statistics, causal ML, experimental design, market-based tests, causal inference, and advertising measurementStackExchange Profile: https://goo.gl/Ywjr2zGoogle Scholar Profile: https://goo.gl/PlTa8iI am an empirical micro-economist. Name: Santosh KC, PhD
Title: San Francisco Bay Area
Location: Assistant Professor at San Jose State University
About: I am an assistant professor at San Jose State University. My background is in Computational Materials Science & Engineering and Condensed Matter Physics. I have more than 12 years of cumulative research experience in this field while working at Universities (UT Dallas, UCSB, SJSU) and in a National Laboratory (ORNL).My research background is in the computational design of materials. I utilize extensive computational methods and techniques to investigate and understand the structure-property relationship in materials for electronic, optical, magnetic, or energy storage devices. I use state-of-the-art electronic structure methods including Density Functional Theory (DFT), Molecular Dynamics (MD) and beyond DFT approaches. Some of my research interest areas are solid-state batteries, semiconductor devices, ferroelectrics, and optoelectronic devices. In addition, I am interested in science education, public outreach, and technological innovations.Moreover, I have managed a research group comprised of graduate and undergraduate students in addition to teaching physics-based materials engineering courses.I am an assistant professor at San Jose State University. About: I’m passionate about international development and the potential and benefits that cooperation can bring to the world in which we live. From a very young age, I started my journey developing projects that addressed violence reduction, educational development, youth empowerment, disaster risk reduction planning, and business development efforts for non-profits fighting social inequalities in Brazil. Since 18, I have served as a Youth Ambassador to the U.S. Department of State, human rights advocate through non-profit work in the United Kingdom, Guatemala, and Senegal, an intern for the International Research and Exchanges Board, and as a business consultant and tech executive supporting development projects across the world. Name: Fred Ferreira
Title: Federal District, Brazil
Location: Editor-executivo e Apresentador do Bom Dia DF
About: Gosto da notícia, do ao vivo, de me conectar com pessoas. Vivo o jornalismo intensamente. Na rua, vou atrás da melhor história, da imagem impactante. No estúdio, é olho no olho com o telespectador, é um bate-papo franco. Sou pós-graduado em Comunicação e Marketing. Estudo frequentemente sobre o comportamento do espectador neste mundo de múltiplas telas. Fiz cursos de liderança. No MBA, pesquisei como o Instagram era usado como ferramenta de marketing. Era o começo da rede social quando ela mais parecia um app de álbum de Fotos.Analiso estratégias de comunicação, discursos e crises. Trabalhei com prefeitos e políticos por três anos. Desde 2008, trabalho na TV Globo Brasília, onde agora sou editor-executivo e apresentador do Bom Dia DF, telejornal líder de audiência das manhãs do Distrito Federal. O foco do Bom Dia DF é ter uma interatividade cada vez maior com o público com muita prestação de serviço, mobilidade, análise política, cobrança por soluções dos problemas comunitários. Queremos saber o que o Brasiliense pensa e como se comporta. Ao assumir a editoria-executiva, o jornal ficou mais vivo, plural, com análise e bem comunitário... O desafio é diário. Antes da TV Globo, passei pelo SBT, Rádio CBN, TV Justiça e EBC e consultorias de marketing e comunicação. Mestre de cerimônias e apresentação de talk-shows corporativos.Gosto da notícia, do ao vivo, de me conectar com pessoas. Vivo o jornalismo intensamente. About: Noemi Bonessio is the inventor of a novel class of metamaterials for vibration control and the creator of METAseismic (University of California startup company). At METAseismic Noemi is creating novel low-embedded-carbon metamaterials with an unprecedented capacity of dampening vibrations, thus reducing up to 30% of the currently used raw structural materials.These materials can absorb up to 90% of harmful vibration energy and can be used in a wide range of applications from devices to spacecraft, vehicles, and components of communities' infrastructure. Name: Bethany Wentz
Title: South Bend-Mishawaka Region
Location: Psychology Researcher at the University of Notre Dame
About: I am a graduate researcher at the University of Notre Dame studying developmental psychology.My research interests focus broadly on adolescents in contexts of ethnopolitical violence and armed conflict. I am also interested in translating research on political violence and its impact on youth into evidence-based interventions to assuage the negative consequences of violence on youth and bolster protective factors in their communities.My interest in youth and ethnopolitical conflict was sparked by my experience as a Peace Corps Volunteer. I served as a Teaching English as a Foreign Language (TEFL) Volunteer in Ukraine from 2012 to 2014. My experience was cut short when violence erupted in the capital of Ukraine and eventually spread to many other cities and towns across the country. The violence ultimately escalated into the ongoing civil war in the eastern Donbas region of the country. Watching this situation unfold in Ukraine solidified my interest in youth and ethnopolitical conflict around the globe.Shortly after my time in Ukraine, I was admitted into the dual master’s degree program in International Peace and Conflict Resolution and Counseling at Arcadia University. This blend of interdisciplinary study allowed me to build skills in program design, evaluation, and grant writing while simultaneously honing interpersonal and therapeutic skills.Ultimately, I am interested in a career in international youth development that will allow me to utilize my advanced research and program design, monitoring, and evaluation skills.When I’m not working, I’m experimenting in the kitchen with international dishes or annoying my cat with my love.I am a graduate researcher at the University of Notre Dame studying developmental psychology. Name: Michelle Hallack
Title: Washington, District of Columbia, United States
Location: Senior Specialist  at Inter-American Development Bank
About: Michelle Hallack is a senior economist responsible for the Energy Division’s knowledge agenda at the Inter-American Development Bank and she is also an Energy Policy Advisor at the Florence School of Regulation. At IADB she works on program and policy issues across Latin America and the Caribbean. She leads the research team and coordinate the research initiatives for the Energy Sector, she is the focal point for hydrogen initiatives and is leading and co-leading new initiatives and products such as the Energy HUB, Electrorating and the Regional Regulatory Data Base Initiative. At FSR she is involved in teaching/training activities, she has been especially interested in developing interactive learning tools and methodologies for academic courses and professional training. Before joining the IADB, Michelle has worked for both public and private sectors around the world (including Latin American, European and Asian countries). She has more than 15 years of experience in research and consulting on regulatory economics. Some of the main results of her work has been published in scientific, professional journals, books and blogs. In particular, she has focused on network industries institutional design and development of new services taking into account the intersection between innovation, public policies and regulation (tools and design). Michelle holds a PhD from the University of Paris Sud XI of Economics, a M.Res from Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, an European Master (EMIN) and a Diploma in Economics Sciences of the State University of Campinas.Michelle Hallack is a senior economist responsible for the Energy Division’s knowledge agenda at the Inter-American Development Bank and she is also an Energy Policy Advisor at the Florence School of Regulation. Name: Mary-Catherine Riley
Title: Phoenix, Arizona, United States
Location: JV Equity & Structured Capital Senior Real Estate Analyst at Berkadia
About: Mary-Catherine Riley is a Senior Real Estate Equity Analyst in Berkadia’s Joint Venture and Structured Capital Group. The team specializes in arranging joint venture equity and structured capital from a broad range of domestic and foreign capital relationships. In her role on the team, she leverages her expertise in real estate to lead analytical projects and supports the team to develop, review, and refine commercial real estate acquisition, value-add, development, and recapitalization financial models with a specific focus on equity. Prior to joining Berkadia, Mary-Catherine was an Associate in the Hospitality Finance Investment Banking Group at Piper Sandler. During her three years on the team, she was primarily focused on providing quantitative analysis and related transaction support to sophisticated debt transactions for hospitality and large issuer clients throughout the country. Prior to joining Piper Sandler in 2019, Mary-Catherine was an investment banking analyst at a Los Angeles-based boutique investment bank where she specialized in merger and acquisition transactions. Mary-Catherine graduated from Scripps College with a bachelor’s degree in environment, economics, and politics. She is also registered with FINRA as a Municipal Securities Representative. Mary-Catherine also leads development efforts at Scripps College as Chair of the College’s Engagement and Outreach Committee.Mary-Catherine Riley is a Senior Real Estate Equity Analyst in Berkadia’s Joint Venture and Structured Capital Group. Name: Alda Metrass, PhD
Title: Washington, District of Columbia, United States
Location: PPP Investment Officer at IFC - International Finance Corporation
About: Alda Metrass is a Global Investment Officer for pre-investment and early stage project development (Upstream) in the Transport sector at IFC (World Bank Group). She has over 15 years of experience in advising public and private sectors in strategic decision-making in the fields of economic regulation and investment in infrastructure (Aviation, Rail, Road and Urban Transport) in Africa, Latin America and the Caribbean, Asia and Europe. She has worked for several IFIs, including the WB Group, AfDB, EBRD, and EIB. Her background combines a Ph.D. (Hons) in Transport Systems and Aviation Policy with a Masters in Management and a Civil Engineering Degree. She is especially interested in PPP structuring, policy reforms, public interest and universal access to services. She has been an Invited Professor at the University of Ibague (Colombia) and lectured on Economic Regulation for the IADB. A national of Portugal, in addition to her native Portuguese, she speaks English, Spanish, French and Italian.Alda Metrass is a Global Investment Officer for pre-investment and early stage project development (Upstream) in the Transport sector at IFC (World Bank Group).
